text:
Chemicals like turpentine, ethanol, and sulfuric
acid are great at dissolving stuff - they

can break down paint, oil, metal, skin, bones,
and more.

But there’s another liquid out there that
can dissolve more substances than perhaps

anything else on Earth: water, which is sometimes
called the “universal solvent.”

Yet this super-dissolver is everywhere; it
falls from the sky and fills our pipes, it’s

what we bathe in, wash our hands with, and
pour down our delicate throats.

If water is such a powerful solvent, why doesn’t
it dissolve everything away?
Welcome to MinuteEarth.

It's true that water is really good at dissolving
lots of stuff.

For a liquid to dissolve something, it has
to pull apart the molecules that make up that
substance, and keep them apart.

Water is pretty much built for that job; its
molecules have strong positive and negative

charges, so they can pull apart and get between
other molecules - or pieces of molecules - with
charged parts.

And lots of different molecules out there
happen to have charged parts, which means

that lots of different substances on our planet
dissolve - at least to some extent - in water.

That’s why water is our go-to for cleaning
stuff - it can dissolve sticky orange juice
right off your counter or blood off your clothes.

But water doesn’t dissolve the counter,
or the clothes.
Or our windows, or streets.

Which at first glance seems like a pretty
lucky coincidence - I mean, it would be not-great

if cleaning something would make it disintegrate,
or if rain could wipe out an entire city.

But the super-dissolving abilities of water
are exactly why our world is built the way
it is - or really, the way it isn’t.

We make our countertops with quartz, our clothes
with cotton, our windows with glass, and our

streets with asphalt because water can't dissolve
these materials - they’re made mostly of
molecules with no charged parts.

It would be silly to build, say, windows out
of something that can dissolve in water, like
sugar…unless you’re going to eat them.

And lots of of the substances that water DOES
dissolve - like washable markers - are things

we’ve engineered so that they can be washed
away; we’ve also engineered versions that

aren’t dissolvable in water for when we
don't want them to be washed away.

By making sure water dissolves what we want
it to - and only what we want it to - we’ve

been able to adapt our lives to a world in
which water dissolves so much stuff.

We humans also literally adapted to a world
in which water dissolves so much stuff - that’s
why we don’t dissolve.

The outer layer of our skin is built in a
way that makes it uncharged - and therefore
undissolvable.

And the membrane surrounding each of the cells
inside us has a similar undissolvable layer.

The only reason we humans exist at all on
this watery planet - or that trees, fish,

bacteria, or anything else exists - is that
we evolved barriers that could keep water
from dissolving us into goo.

Any life forms that didn’t were simply dead
in the water.

Realizing our entire planet is built around
water’s awesome dissolving ability has changed

how I see the world - which is one of our
goals at MinuteEarth.
